ControlledConcept.gml:description: An Earth Material composed of an aggregation of particles of Earth Material, possibly including other Compound Materials. This is 'top' of lithology category hierarchy, and should be used to indicate 'any rock or unconsolidated material'. Source: NADM C1, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:compound_material
ControlledConcept.name: Compound material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Coarse-grained material composed of angular broken rock fragments; the fragments typically have sharp edges and unworn corners. The fragments may be held together by a mineral cement, or in a fine-grained matrix. Clasts may be of any composition or origin. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:breccia
ControlledConcept.name: Breccia

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Material of unspecified consolidation state formed by geological modification of pre-existing materials outside the realm of igneous and sedimentary processes. Includes rocks formed by impact metamorphism, standard dynamothermal metamorphism, brittle deformation, weathering, metasomatism and hydrothermal alteration (diagenesis is a sedimentary process in this context). Source: SLTTm 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:composite_genesis_material
ControlledConcept.name: Composite genesis material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Material formed as a result brittle faulting, composed of greater than 10 percent matrix; matrix is fine-grained material caused by tectonic grainsize reduction. Includes cohesive (cataclasite series) and non-cohesive (breccia-gouge series) material. Source: this vocabulary; SLTTm 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:fault_related_material
ControlledConcept.name: Fault-related material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fault material with features such as void spaces (filled or unfilled), or unconsolidated matrix material between fragments, indicating loss of cohesion during deformation. Includes fault-related breccia and gouge. Source: SLTTm 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:breccia_gouge_series
ControlledConcept.name: Breccia-gouge series

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fault-related rock that maintained primary cohesion during deformation, with matrix comprising 50 to 90 percent of rock mass; matrix is fine-grained material caused by tectonic grainsize reduction. Includes cataclasite, protocataclasite and ultracataclasite. Source: Sibson, 1977; Scholz, 1990; Snoke and Tullis, 1998; Barker, 1998 Appendix II; NADM SLTTm, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:cataclasite_series
ControlledConcept.name: Cataclasite series

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock forming a hard crust or layer at or near the Earth's surface at the time of formation, e.g. in the upper horizons of a soil, characterized by structures indicative of pedogenic origin. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:duricrust
ControlledConcept.name: Duricrust

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Highly aluminous material containing abundant aluminium hydroxides (gibbsite, less commonly boehmite, diaspore) and aluminium-substituted iron oxides or hydroxides and generally minor or negligible kaolin minerals; may contain up to 20 percent quartz. Commonly has a pisolitic or nodular texture, and may be cemented. Source: Eggleton, 2001
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:bauxite
ControlledConcept.name: Bauxite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: CompoundMaterial composed of an aggregation of particles that do not adhere to each other strongly enough that the aggregate can be considered a solid in its own right. Source: NGMDB
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:unconsolidated_material
ControlledConcept.name: Unconsolidated material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unconsolidated material known to have artificial (human-related) origin. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:anthropogenic_unconsolidated_material
ControlledConcept.name: Anthropogenic unconsolidated material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unconsolidated material known to have natural, ie. not human-made, origin. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:natural_unconsolidated_material
ControlledConcept.name: Natural unconsolidated material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unconsolidated material consisting of an aggregation of particles transported or deposited by air, water or ice, or that accumulated by other natural agents, such as chemical precipitation, and that forms in layers on the Earth's surface. Includes epiclastic deposits. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment in which at least 50 percent of the constituent particles were derived from erosion, weathering, or mass-wasting of pre-existing earth materials, and transported to the place of deposition by mechanical agents such as water, wind, ice and gravity. Source: SLTTs, 2004; Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:clastic_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Clastic sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unsorted or poorly sorted, clastic sediment with a wide range of particle sizes such that it cannot be assigned to any other class. Source: Fairbridge and Bourgeois 1978
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:diamicton
ControlledConcept.name: Diamicton

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment containing greater than 30 percent gravel-size particles (greater than 2.0 mm diameter). Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:gravel
ControlledConcept.name: Gravel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Clastic sediment in which less than 30 percent of particles are gravel (greater than 2 mm in diameter) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005; NGMDB
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:sand
ControlledConcept.name: Sand

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Clastic sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1. Clasts may be of any composition or origin. Source: based on SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:mud
ControlledConcept.name: Mud

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment that consists of at least 50 percent material produced by chemical (organic or inorganic) processes within the basin of deposition. Includes organic-rich, non-clastic siliceous, carbonate, evaporite, iron-rich, and phosphatic sediment classes. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:chemical_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Chemical sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment composed of greater than 50 percent material of biogenic origin. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:biogenic_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Biogenic sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Mud with a sand to mud ratio less than 1 to 9 that contains at least 30 percent skeletal remains of pelagic organisms. Less than 1 percent gravel and less than 50 percent carbonate minerals. Source: based on Bates and Jackson 1987 & Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:ooze
ControlledConcept.name: Ooze

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:iron_rich_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Iron rich sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phosphatic_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Phosphatic sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition. Source: NGMDB 2008; Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:non_clastic_siliceous_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Non-clastic siliceous sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment with color, composition, texture and apparent density indicating greater than 50 percent organic content by weight on a moisture-free basis. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:organic_rich_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Organic rich sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unconsolidated organic-rich sediment composed of at least 50 percent semi-carbonised plant remains; individual remains commonly seen with unaided eye; yellowish brown to brownish black; generally fibrous texture; can be plastic or friable. In its natural state it can be readily cut and has a very high moisture content, generally greater than 90 percent. Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:peat
ControlledConcept.name: Peat

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sediment in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals calcite, aragonite and dolomite, in particles of intrabasinal origin. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sediment with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. Source: after SLTTs 2004, Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:dolomitic_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Dolomitic sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sediment with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes lime-sediments. Source: after Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:calcareous_carbonate_sediment
ControlledConcept.name: Calcareous carbonate sediment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sediment composed of more than 25 percent gravel-sized clasts (maximum diameter more than 2 mm). Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_gravel
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate gravel

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sediment composed of more than 75 percent sand-sized clasts (maximum diameter between 32 microns and 2 mm). Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_sand
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate sand

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sediment composed of more than 75 percent mud-sized clasts (maximum diameter less than 32 microns). Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_mud
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate mud

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unconsolidated pyroclastic material in which greater than 75 percent of the fragments are deposited as a direct result of volcanic processes and the deposit has not been reworked by epiclastic processes. Includes ash, lapilli tephra, bomb tephra, block tephra and unconsolidated agglomerate. Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:tephra
ControlledConcept.name: Tephra

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Tephra in which less than 25 percent of fragments are greater than 64 mm in longest dimension Source: Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:ash_and_lapilli
ControlledConcept.name: Ash and lapilli

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Tephra in which more than 25 percent of particles are greater than 64 mm in largest dimension. Includes ash breccia, bomb tephra and block tephra of Gillespie and Styles (1999) Source: Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:ash_breccia_bomb_or_block_tephra
ControlledConcept.name: Ash breccia, bomb, or block tephra

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Consolidated aggregate of one or more EarthMaterials, or a body of undifferentiated mineral matter, or of solid organic material. Includes mineral aggregates such as granite, shale, marble; glassy matter such as obsidian; and organic material such a coal. Excludes unconsolidated materials. Source: Jackson, 1997; NADM C1 2004; Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:rock
ControlledConcept.name: Rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock that is too fine grained to categorize in more detail. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:aphanite
ControlledConcept.name: Aphanite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock formed as a result of igneous processes, for example intrusion and cooling of magma in the crust, or volcanic eruption. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock that consists of greater than 90 percent glass. Source: This vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:glassy_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Glassy igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock with 'exotic' mineralogical, textural or field setting characteristics; typically dark colored, with abundant phenocrysts. Criteria include: presence of greater than 10 percent melilite or leucite; presence of kalsilite; greater than 50 percent carbonate minerals. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:exotic_composition_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Exotic composition igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Kimberlite, lamproite, or lamprophyre. Generally are potassic, mafic or ultramafic rocks. Olivine (commonly serpentinized in kimberlite), and phlogopite are significant constituents. Source: based on LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:exotic_alkaline_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Exotic alkaline rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock containing greater than 10 percent melilite or kalsilite. Typically undersaturated, ultrapotassic (kalsilitic rocks) or calcium-rich (melilitic rocks) mafic or ultramafic rocks. Source: based on LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:exotic_alkalic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Exotic alkalic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock composed of more than 50 percent modal carbonate minerals. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonatite
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonatite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock in which greater than 75 percent of the rock consists of fragments produced as a result of igneous rock-forming process. Includes pyroclastic rocks, autobreccia associated with lava flows and intrusive breccias. Excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes. Source: NGMDB 2008
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:fragmental_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Fragmental igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragmental igneous rock that consists of greater than 75 percent fragments produced as a direct result of eruption or extrusion of magma from within the earth onto its surface. Includes autobreccia associated with lava flows and excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes. Source: based on LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:pyroclastic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Pyroclastic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pyroclastic rock in which greater than 25 percent of particles are greater than 64 mm in largest dimension. Includes agglomerate, pyroclastic breccia of Gillespie and Styles (1999) Source: Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:tuff_breccia_agglomerate_or_pyroclastic_breccia
ControlledConcept.name: Tuff-breccia, agglomerate, or pyroclastic breccia

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pyroclastic rock in which less than 25 percent of rock by volume are more than 64 mm in longest diameter. Includes tuff, lapilli tuff, and lapillistone. Source: Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:ash_tuff_lapillistone_and_lapilli_tuff
ControlledConcept.name: Ash tuff, lapillistone, and lapilli tuff

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock in which greater than 10 percent of rock is individual crystals that can be discerned with the unaided eye. Bounding grain size is on the order of 32 to 100 microns. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phaneritic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Phaneritic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and/or plagioclase. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 2, 3, 4 and 5 as alkali granite, granite, granodiorite or tonalite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:granitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Granitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 5. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:tonalite
ControlledConcept.name: Tonalite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and plagioclase (typically sodic) in variable amounts, usually with biotite and/or hornblende. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 3. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:granite
ControlledConcept.name: Granite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting essentially of quartz, sodic plagioclase and lesser amounts of alkali feldspar with minor hornblende and biotite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 4. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:granodiorite
ControlledConcept.name: Granodiorite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and plagioclase; minor quartz or nepheline may be present, along with pyroxene, amphibole or biotite. Includes rocks classified in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 as syenite or monzonite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:syenitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Syenitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock containing almost equal amounts of plagioclase and alkali feldspar with minor amphibole and/or pyroxene and little or no quartz. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 8. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:monzonite
ControlledConcept.name: Monzonite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Coarse grained crystalline rock consisting mainly of alkali feldspar with subordinate sodic plagioclase, biotite, pyroxene, amphibole and occasional fayalite; minor quartz or nepheline may be present. Defined modally in QAPF Field 7. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:syenite
ControlledConcept.name: Syenite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock with M less than 90, consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 as diorite, monzodiorite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:dioritic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Dioritic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite; colour index M less than 90, sodic plagioclase (An0-An50). Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 10 as diorite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:diorite
ControlledConcept.name: Diorite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting of sodic plagioclase (An0 to An50), alkali feldspar, hornblende and biotite, with or without pyroxene. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9 as monzodiorite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:monzodiorite
ControlledConcept.name: Monzodiorite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock composed of 65 percent or more of calcic plagioclase and up to 20 percent quartz or up to 10 percent feldspathoid. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 as gabbro or monzogabbro and foid-bearing varieties. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:gabbroic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Gabbroic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting of calcic plagioclase (An50 to An100), alkali feldspar, hornblende and biotite, with or without pyroxene. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9 as monzogabbro. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:monzogabbro
ControlledConcept.name: Monzogabbro

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock composed essentially of calcic plagioclase (An50 to An100), pyroxene and iron oxides. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 10 as gabbro. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:gabbro
ControlledConcept.name: Gabbro

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock in which M is less than 90, composed of feldspathoids as 10-60 percent of the felsic minerals, calcic plagioclase (An50-An100) and large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 14. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foid_gabbroic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Foid gabbroic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock in which M is less than 90, composed of feldspathoids as 10-60 percent of the felsic minerals, sodic plagioclase (An0-An50) and large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 14. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foid_dioritic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Foid dioritic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Leucocratic, phaneritic crystalline rock composed of feldspathoids as 10-60 percent of the felsic minerals, alkali feldspar and mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 11. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foid_syenitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Foid syenitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: General term for a leucocratic phaneritic crystalline rock consisting essentially of plagioclase, often with small amounts of pyroxene; colour index M less than 10. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 10 as anorthosite. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:anorthositic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Anorthositic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline rock containing more than 60 percent feldspathoids in total light-coloured constituents. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15 Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foidolite
ControlledConcept.name: Foidolite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock that contains greater than 60 percent quartz. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:quartz_rich_phaneritic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Quartz rich phaneritic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Exceptionally coarse grained crystalline rock with interlocking crystals; most grains are 1cm or more diameter; composition is generally that of granite, but the term may refer to the coarse grained facies of any type of igneous rock;usually found as irregular dikes, lenses, or veins associated with plutons or batholiths. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:pegmatite
ControlledConcept.name: Pegmatite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Light coloured crystalline rock, characterized by a fine grained allotriomorphic-granular (aplitic, saccharoidal or xenomorphic) texture; typically granitic composition, consisting of quartz, K-feldspar and sodic plagioclase. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:aplite
ControlledConcept.name: Aplite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock that contains conspicuous phenocrysts in a finer grained groundmass; groundmass itself may be phaneritic or fine-grained. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:porphyry
ControlledConcept.name: Porphyry

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Dark colored gabbroic (basaltic) or dioritic (andesitic) rock intermediate in grain size between basalt and gabbro and composed of plagioclase, pyroxene and opaque minerals; often with ophitic texture. Typically occurs as hypabyssal intrusions. Includes dolerite, microdiorite, diabase and microgabbro. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; LeMaitre et al 2002; Gillespie and Styles, 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:doleritic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Doleritic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Aphanitic or porphyritic igneous rock composed of greater than 10 percent groundmass, in which most of the crystals cannot be distinguished with the unaided eye; grainsize is typically less than 1mm. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:fine_grained_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Fine grained igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine grained crystalline rock, usually porphyritic, consisting of plagioclase (frequently zoned from labradorite to oligoclase), pyroxene, hornblende and/or biotite; color index M less than 35. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field O2 as andesite. Fine grained equivalent of dioritic rock. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:andesitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Andesitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine grained or porphyritic crystalline rock composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene; volcanic equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5 or chemically in TAS Field O3. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:dacitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Dacitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine-grained volcanic rock consisting of alkali feldspar and minor mafic minerals, typically amphibole or mica; typically porphyritic. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 or chemically in TAS Field T as trachyte or latite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:trachytic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Trachytic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine-grained igneous rock, typically porphyritic, consisting of quartz and alkali feldspar (often as phenocrysts), with minor plagioclase and biotite, in a microcrystalline, cryptocrystalline or glassy groundmass. Flow texture is common. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 2 and 3 or chemically in TAS Field R as rhyolite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:rhyolitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Rhyolitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine grained igneous rock containing feldspathoids and in which alkali feldspar is thought to be more abundant than plagioclase. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 11 and 12, and TAS field Ph. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phonolitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Phonolitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine-grained or porphyritic igneous rock with less than 20 percent quartz, and less than 10 percent feldspathoid minerals, in which the ratio of plagioclase to alkali feldspar is greater than 66 percent, and the color index is greater than 35. Typically composed of calcic plagioclase and clinopyroxene; phenocrysts typically include one or more of calcic plagioclase, clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene, and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field B as basalt. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:basaltic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Basaltic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine grained crystalline igneous rock containing essential feldspathoids and in which plagioclase is more abundant than alkali feldspar. Includes rocks classified in QAPF field 14 or chemically in TAS field U1 as basanite or tephrite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:tephritic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Tephritic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fine grained crystalline rock containing more than 60 percent feldspathoids in total light-coloured constituents. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15 or chemically in TAS field F. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foiditic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Foiditic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock with more than 63 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:acidic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Acidic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock with between 52 and 63 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:intermediate_composition_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Intermediate composition igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock with between 45 and 52 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:basic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Basic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous rock with less than 45 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:ultrabasic_igneous_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Ultrabasic igneous rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Ultramafic rock that consists of greater than 40 percent hornblende plus pyroxene and has a hornblende to pyroxene ratio greater than 1. Includes olivine hornblendite, olivine-pyroxene hornblendite, pyroxene hornblendite, and hornblendite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:hornblendite
ControlledConcept.name: Hornblendite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Ultramafic phaneritic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as olivine pyroxenite, olivine-hornblende pyroxenite, pyroxenite, orthopyroxenite, clinopyroxenite and websterite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:pyroxenite
ControlledConcept.name: Pyroxenite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Ultramafic volcanic rock, typically with spinifex texture of intergrown skeletal and bladed olivine and pyroxene crystals set in abundant glass. Includes picrite, komatiite and meimechite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:komatiitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Komatiitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Ultramafic rock consisting of more than 40 percent (by volume) olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole and little or no feldspar. Commonly altered to serpentinite. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as dunite, harzburgite, lherzolite, wehrlite, olivinite, pyroxene peridotite, pyroxene hornblende peridotite or hornblende peridotite. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:peridotite
ControlledConcept.name: Peridotite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock formed by geological modification of pre-existing rocks outside the realm of igneous and sedimentary processes. Includes rocks formed by impact metamorphism, standard dynamothermal metamorphism, brittle deformation, weathering, metasomatism and hydrothermal alteration (diagenesis is a sedimentary process in this context). Source: SLTTm 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:composite_genesis_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Composite genesis rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock that contains features indicative of shock metamorphism, such as microscopic planar deformation features within grains or shatter cones. Includes breccias and melt rocks. Source: Stöffler and Grieve 2007; Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:impact_metamorphic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Impact metamorphic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock formed by solid-state mineralogical, chemical and/or structural changes to a pre-existing rock, in response to marked changes in temperature, pressure, shearing stress and chemical environment; generally at depth in the crust. Source: Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:metamorphic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Metamorphic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Silicate metamorphic rock that is pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale that typically consists of darker and lighter parts; the darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance. Source: after IUGS SCMR 2007 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:migmatite
ControlledConcept.name: Migmatite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Granofels composed of a mosaic of equidimensional grains in a characteristically granoblastic or decussate matrix; porphyroblasts or relict phenocrysts may be present. Typically formed by contact metamorphism. Source: IUGS SCMR 2007 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:hornfels
ControlledConcept.name: Hornfels

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Phaneritic metamorphic rock with granoblastic fabric and very little or no foliation (less than 10 percent of the mineral grains in the rock are elements in a planar or linear fabric). Source: SLTTm 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:granofels
ControlledConcept.name: Granofels

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock in which 10 percent or more of the contained mineral grains are elements in a planar or linear fabric. Cataclastic or glassy character precludes classification with this concept. Source: based on NADM SLTT metamorphic
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:foliated_metamorphic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Foliated metamorphic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Foliated phaneritic metamorphic rock with well developed, continuous schistosity (greater than 50 percent of mineral grains with a tabular, lamellar, or prismatic crystallographic habit that are oriented in a continuous planar or linear fabric). Source: SLTTm 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:schist
ControlledConcept.name: Schist

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Compact, fine grained rock with an average grain size less than 0.032 millimeter and a well developed schistosity (slaty cleavage), and hence can be split into slabs or thin plates. Source: NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0; Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:slate
ControlledConcept.name: Slate

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock with a well developed, continuous schistosity, an average grain size between 0.1 and 0.5 millimeters, and a silvery sheen on cleavage surfaces. Individual phyllosilicate grains are barely visible with the unaided eye. Source: IUGS SCMR 2007 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phyllite
ControlledConcept.name: Phyllite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock characterised by a foliation resulting from tectonic grain size reduction, in which more than 10 percent of the rock volume has undergone grain size reduction. Includes protomylonite, mylonite, ultramylonite, phyllonite and blastomylonite. Source: Marshak & Mitra 1988
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:mylonitic_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Mylonitic rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Mylonitic rock composed largely of fine-grained mica that imparts a sheen to foliation surfaces; may have flaser lamination, isoclinal folding, and deformed veins, which indicate significant shearing. Macroscopically resembles phyllite, but formed by mechanical degradation of initially coarser rock. Source: NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0; Marshak & Mitra 1988
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phyllonite
ControlledConcept.name: Phyllonite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Foliated metamorphic rock with bands or lenticles rich in granular minerals alternating with bands or lenticles rich in minerals with a flaky or elongate prismatic habit. Mylonitic foliation or well developed, continuous schistosity (greater than 50 percent of the rock consists of grains participate in a planar or linear fabric) precludes classification with this concept. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:gneiss
ControlledConcept.name: Gneiss

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than or equal to 75 percent quartz; typically granoblastic texture. Source: after Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:quartzite
ControlledConcept.name: Quartzite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock consisting of more than 75 percent serpentine-group minerals, eg. antigorite, chrysotile or lizardite; accessory chlorite, talc and magnetite may be present; derived from hydration of ferromagnesian silicate minerals such as olivine and pyroxene. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:serpentinite
ControlledConcept.name: Serpentinite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock composed of 75 percent or more (by volume) omphacite and garnet, both of which are present as major constituents, the amount of neither of them being higher than 75 percent (by volume); the presence of plagioclase precludes classification as an eclogite. Source: IUGS SCMR 2007 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:eclogite
ControlledConcept.name: Eclogite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite), which combined form 75 percent or more of the rock, and both of which are present as major constituents. The amphibole constitutes 50 percent or more of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount of 30 percent or more; other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Source: Coutinho et al. 2007, IUGS SCMR chapter 8 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/)
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:amphibolite
ControlledConcept.name: Amphibolite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than 75 percent fine- to coarse-grained recrystallized calcite and/or dolomite; usually with a granoblastic, saccharoidal texture. Source: IUGS SCMR 2007 (http://www.bgs.ac.uk/SCMR/), SLTTm1.0 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:marble
ControlledConcept.name: Marble

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Rock formed by accumulation and cementation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or as a result of other natural agents, such as precipitation from solution, the accumulation of organic material, or from biogenic processes, including secretion by organisms. Includes epiclastic deposits. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock in which at least 50 percent of the constituent particles were derived from erosion, weathering, or mass-wasting of pre-existing earth materials, and transported to the place of deposition by mechanical agents such as water, wind, ice and gravity. Source: SLTTs, 2004; Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:clastic_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Clastic sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Clastic sedimentary rock consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1. Clasts may be of any composition or origin. Source: Pettijohn et al. 1987 referenced in Hallsworth & Knox 1999; extrapolated from Folk, 1954, Figure 1a
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:mudstone
ControlledConcept.name: Mudstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Laminated mudstone that will part or break along thin, closely spaced layers parallel to stratification. Source: NADM SLTT sedimentary; Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:shale
ControlledConcept.name: Shale

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Clastic sedimentary rock in which less than 30 percent of particles are greater than 2 mm in diameter (gravel) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. Source: SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:sandstone
ControlledConcept.name: Sandstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Coarse grained sedimentary rock composed of at least 30 percent rounded to subangular fragments larger than 2 mm in diameter; typically contains finer grained material in interstices between larger fragments. Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005; SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:conglomerate
ControlledConcept.name: Conglomerate

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sandstone that contains between 15 and 75 percent matrix of unspecified origin. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:wackestone
ControlledConcept.name: Wackestone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Unsorted or poorly sorted, clastic sedimentary rock with a wide range of particle sizes such that it cannot be assigned to any other class. Source: Fairbridge and Bourgeois 1978
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:diamictite
ControlledConcept.name: Diamictite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals calcite, aragonite and dolomite, in particles of intrabasinal origin. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes limestone and dolomitic limestone. Source: SLTTs 2004; Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:calcareous_carbonate_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Calcareous carbonate sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. Includes dolostone, lime dolostone and magnesite-stone. Source: after SLTTs 2004, Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:dolomitic_or_magnesian_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Dolomitic or magnesian sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with matrix-supported fabric, composed of more than 75 percent mud-sized grains (maximum diameter less than 32 microns). The original depositional texture is preserved. Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999; SLTTs, 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_mudstone
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate mudstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with discernible mud supported depositional texture and containing greater than 10 percent grains. Source: Dunham 1962
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_wackestone
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate wackestone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with discernible grain supported depositional texture, containing greater than 10 percent grains; intergranular spaces are filled by matrix. Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:packstone
ControlledConcept.name: Packstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary rock with recognizable depositional fabric that is grain-supported; contains little or no mud matrix. Source: Dunham 1962
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:grainstone
ControlledConcept.name: Grainstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary carbonate rock with preserved biogenic texture, whose original components were bound and encrusted together during deposition by the action of plants and animals during deposition, and remained substantially in the position of growth. Source: Hallsworth and Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:boundstone
ControlledConcept.name: Boundstone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate reef rock consisting of a rigid framework of colonies, shells or skeletons, with internal cavities filled with fine sediment; usually created through the activities of colonial organisms. Source: Hallsworth & Knox 1999; SLTTs, 2004, Table 15-3-1
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:framestone
ControlledConcept.name: Framestone

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate rock of indeterminate mineralogy in which diagenetic processes have obliterated any original depositional texture. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:crystalline_carbonate
ControlledConcept.name: Crystalline carbonate

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock with color, composition, texture and apparent density indicating greater than 50 percent organic content by weight on a moisture-free basis. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:organic_rich_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Organic rich sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Hard, black, organic rich sedimentary rock that yields greater than 8,300 Btu on a moist, mineral-matter-free basis, or contains greater than 69 percent fixed carbon on a dry, mineral-matter-free basis; formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Source: ASTM 2002; Schopf 1956
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:coal
ControlledConcept.name: Coal

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:non_clastic_siliceous_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Non-clastic siliceous sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by biological processes within the basin of deposition. Source: based on NADM SLTT sedimentary; Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:biogenic_silica_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Biogenic silica sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Source: Hallsworth and Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:iron_rich_sedimentary_rock
ControlledConcept.name: Iron rich sedimentary rock

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary rock in which at least 50 percent of the primary or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals. Most commonly occurs as a bedded primary or reworked secondary marine rock, composed of microcrystalline carbonate fluorapatite in the form of lamina, pellets, oolites and nodules, and skeletal, shell and bone fragments. Source: Hallsworth&Knox 1999, Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phosphorite
ControlledConcept.name: Phosphorite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous material with more than 63 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:acidic_igneous_material
ControlledConcept.name: Acidic igneous material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Earth material formed as a result of igneous processes, eg. intrusion and cooling of magma in the crust, volcanic eruption. Source: This vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:igneous_material
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous material with between 45 and 52 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:basic_igneous_material
ControlledConcept.name: Basic igneous material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous material with between 52 and 63 percent SiO2. Source: after LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:intermediate_composition_igneous_material
ControlledConcept.name: Intermediate composition igneous material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Igneous material of unspecified consolidation state in which greater than 75 percent of the rock consists of fragments produced as a result of igneous rock-forming process. Source: CGI concepts task group
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:fragmental_igneous_material
ControlledConcept.name: Fragmental igneous material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragmental igneous material that consists of more than 75 percent of particles formed by disruption as a direct result of volcanic action. Source: LeMaitre et al. 2002
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:pyroclastic_material
ControlledConcept.name: Pyroclastic material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material of unspecified consolidation state in which at least 50 percent of the constituent particles were derived from erosion, weathering, or mass-wasting of pre-existing earth materials, and transported to the place of deposition by mechanical agents such as water, wind, ice and gravity. Source: SLTTs, 2004; Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:clastic_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Clastic sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Material formed by accumulation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or material that accumulated by other natural agents such as chemical precipitation from solution or secretion by organisms. Includes both sediment and sedimentary rock. Includes epiclastic deposits. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material in which 50 percent or more of the primary sedimentary material is organic carbon. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:organic_rich_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Organic rich sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:phosphate_rich_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Phosphate rich sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material of unspecified consolidation state that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:iron_rich_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Iron rich sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals calcite, aragonite and dolomite, in particles of intrabasinal origin. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:carbonate_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Carbonate sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary material of unspecified consolidation state with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes lime-sediments, limestone and dolomitic limestone. Source: after Hallsworth & Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:calcareous_carbonate_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Calcareous carbonate sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Carbonate sedimentary material of unspecified consolidation degree with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. Includes dolomite sediment, dolostone, lime dolostone and magnesite-stone. Source: after SLTTs 2004, Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:dolomitic_or_magnesian_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Dolomitic or magnesian sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Sedimentary material that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition. Source: SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:non_clastic_siliceous_sedimentary_material
ControlledConcept.name: Non-clastic siliceous sedimentary material

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Nonclastic sedimentary rock composed of at least 50 percent non-carbonate salts, including chloride, sulfate or borate minerals; formed through precipitation of mineral salts from a saline solution (non-carbonate salt rock). Source: Jackson 1997; SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:evaporite
ControlledConcept.name: Evaporite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Material known to have artificial (human-related) origin; insufficient information to classify in more detail. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:SimpleLithology:200811:anthropogenic_material
ControlledConcept.name: Anthropogenic material
